util

    • Method Detail

      • setHelp

        public Args.Matcher<T> setHelp(java.lang.String... s)
        Allows one to provide detailed help for a given argument; this will appear in the "Options" section for that argument. As with Args.setHelp(), you are responsible for breaking the information up into multiple lines as necessary.

      • setParamSample

        public Args.Matcher<T> setParamSample(java.lang.String s)
        For printing sample usage in documentation output, e.g. the "number" in "--count=<number>".

        The default parameter sample is "value". Note that this automatically call setAllowsParam() since such is implied.

      • onlyIf

        public Args.Matcher<T> onlyIf(Args.Matcher<?> other)

        Asserts that the argument is only valid when "other" is also present (order of arguments does not matter). This affects both validation and documentation. For example, in the help synopsis, the user will see something like 

        ... [-other [-this]] ...
        instead of 
        ... [-other] [-this] ...
        - and the presence of "-this" as input without "-other" will cause a validation failure.

        Finally, if this argument is designated as required via Matcher.setRequired(), the requirement is only checked if "other" is also present.

      • setRequired

        public Args.Matcher<T> setRequired()
        Indicates that the argument is required. For named (non-wildcard) arguments it only makes sense that a parameter is required (why else would you require the argument), so setRequiresParam() is automatically invoked as well.

      • setAllowsParam

        public Args.Matcher<T> setAllowsParam()
        Indicates a named argument allows an optional parameter value. However, this will NOT negate a previous call to setRequiresParam() (it effectively becomes a no-op).

        This method call is unnecessary for unnamed wildcard Matchers, and is automatically invoked by any method that implies parameterization for a named Matcher.

      • setRequiresParam

        public Args.Matcher<T> setRequiresParam()
        Indicates a named argument requires a parameter value. It is not necessary to call setAllowsParam() as well. This does NOT make the argument required, only the parameter(s) for the argument.

      • setMultiParam

        public Args.Matcher<T> setMultiParam()
        Indicates this argument allows multiple parameter values, e.g. "--xxx hello world today". For unnamed/wildcard arguments, this means we can match multiple values in sequence. When combined with setRequiresParam(), a minimum of one parameter is required.

      • setRequiresMultiParam

        public Args.Matcher<T> setRequiresMultiParam()
        A shortcut to setRequiresParam().setMultiParam().

      • setRequiredAndMultiParam

        public Args.Matcher<T> setRequiredAndMultiParam()
        A shortcut to setRequired().setMultiParam(); the argument AND at least one parameter value are required (for wildcards, the parameters are the argument itself, so the call is still valid and yields sensible results, i.e. at least one value is required).

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        Mainly for debugging match() results.
        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object

      • found

        public boolean found()
        Indicates whether the argument was found in the user input. Warning: A Matcher can return true for both found() and failed() when invalid input is captured.
        Returns:
        true if a matching argument was found i.e. "captured".

      • failed

        public boolean failed()
        Indicates whether there were user errors when validating this Matcher.

      • getParam

        public T getParam(T defaultValue)
        Obtains the parameter value.
        Parameters:
        defaultValue - This will be returned if the argument was not found, or if it was found but the parameter was optional and not provided. Note that for the case of "--arg=" defaultValue will be returned. Finally, if this Matcher is configured as a multi-parameter argument an IllegalStateException will be thrown.

      • getParam

        public T getParam()
        Same as getParam(T) but returns null when no parameter was provided by the user.

      • getParams

        public java.util.List<T> getParams(java.util.List<T> defaultValues)
        Obtains a list of values for multi-parameter arguments.
        Parameters:
        defaultValues - A list of default values. Null is permitted.
        Returns:
        The user-input values if any were provided; otherwise defaultValues. Note that for the case of "--arg= " defaultValues will be returned.

      • getParams

        public java.util.List<T> getParams()
        Obtains a list of values for multi-parameter arguments.
        Returns:
        A non-null list if setMultiParam() was used; otherwise null.

      • getName

        public java.lang.String getName()
        Obtains the name provided by the user for named (non-wildcard) arguments. Sometimes useful when an argument allows more than one name.

      • parseIntParam

        public static java.lang.Integer parseIntParam(java.lang.String raw)
        A convenience function for integer conversion of raw String values. Example usage: 
                Matcher matcher=args.add(Matcher::parseIntParam, "--number");
